GAP Modeling Database Parameters.habitat_description:
The Northern Bobwhite (Colinus virginianus; hereafter, Bobwhite) can be found in the southeastern U.S., parts of Upper Midwest, and the southern Great Plains west to eastern Colorado and New Mexico (Kingery 1998, NatureServe 2004).  In 1985, it was reintroduced in Buenos Aries Wildlife Refuge in the Alter Valley in southern Arizona (Arizona Game and Fish Department 2001). 

The Bobwhite is associated with a variety of early-successional stage habitats, such as what exists in agricultural areas, brushy pastures, grassy roadsides, grasslands, open park-like mixed deciduous and pine woodlands and savannas, grass-brush rangelands (Brennan 1999), overgrown fields, native prairies, woodland edges (Fussell 1994), and gaps made in the forest by logging (Stupka 1963).  In Tennessee, they are most abundant in a mosaic of agricultural fields, wooded hedgerows, and fallow fields dominated by broom sedge (Nicholson 1997).  In the Upper Coastal Plains of Georgia, White et al. (2005) located nests in fallow fields, open-canopy planted pine stands, young pine plantations, and pine-plantations that were >7 yr old and had been row-thinned.  None were found in hardwood stands >5 yrs old.  All of the nests that they found in closed-canopy pine stands were <25 m from the stand’s edge.  Guthery et al. (2001) examined Bobwhite habitat in an Oklahoma landscape and found brushy prairie and early-successional woodlands to be beneficial while mature woodlands were detrimental to Bobwhite populations.

In general, Bobwhite habitat is characterized by an open canopy or grassland with the presence of grasses, forbs, shrubs, and intermittent small patches of bare ground among stems and clumps of herbaceous vegetation (Brennan 1999, White et al. 2005).  Their abundance and nest site selection are influenced at the landscape scale by landscape composition (percent of landcover types) and landscape configuration (patch diversity; White et al. 2005).  The landscapes historically created by agriculture, a patchwork of croplands, fallow fields, hardwood forests, and pine plantations, were beneficial to the Bobwhite because of its preference for early-successional habitats and ecotones (Brennan 1999, Gutherey et al. 2001, White et al. 2005).  Modern agriculture has trended towards larger, “cleaner” fields without these features, which has been implicated in large scale population declines (Brennan 1999).  Although the agricultural landscapes that preceded intensive farming methods were beneficial to Bobwhites, they were not required; natural habitat types alone can host high densities of Bobwhites (Guthery et al. 2001).  

Within woodlands, Bobwhites utilize early successional conditions that are created by disturbance events such as fires, logging, and agriculture (Brennan 1999). In southern pine forests, frequent (1-3 yr intervals) fires are necessary to maintain the open conditions needed by Bobwhites (Brennan 1999).  They are commonly found in pine woodlands with well developed grass ground cover and little or no midstory, such as longleaf-slash, loblolly-shortleaf in the Atlantic Coastal Plain and Piedmont and virginia pine, shortleaf pine in the Ridge and Valley, Highland Rim, Cumberland Plateau and Peidmont (Hunter 1990).  Bobwhite are typically absent from high-density pine plantations (Brennan 1999).  Well-drained upland pine and mixed deciduous woodlands with <50% canopy cover offer the “best opportunities for bobwhite management” (Brennan 1999). 

Bobwhite also exist in rangelands landscapes that are not dominated by forests or woodlands.  Some strong Bobwhite populations occur in north Texas, south Texas, and Oklahoma in rangeland habitats where agriculture is absent (Guthery et al. 2001).  They are also found in Cross Timbers forests, tallgrass prairies, sandsage-grasslands, and brushy prairies (Guthery et al. 2001).  Open grasslands in the West can be suitable if they are mixed with small shrubs, thorny bushes, or trees (Brennan 1999).  In rangelands, they exist in early and late successional stage habitats and they benefit from light cattle grazing (Brennan 1999).  Brushy draws, fencerows, and woodlots are also used in the Midwest and Great Plains. 

Bobwhites place nests in woodlands or fields (Harrison 1975), usually within 15-20 m of an opening such as a field or road.  The nest is located on ground that is partially covered with standing vegetation <45 cm tall (Brennan 1999) and placed in a tuft of dead or living grass with surrounding herbaceous plants covering it and often woven into an arch above it (Harrison 1975).  After their eggs hatch, the parents lead the fledgling to habitat that is more open than where nest was placed.  These brood habitats can be over 500 m from the nest.

The elevation range within which Bobwhite are found in New Mexico and Arizona is 942-1,830m (New Mexico Department of Game and Fish 2002, Arizona Game and Fish Department 2001). 

N. Tarr, 18Nov2011.

GAP Modeling Database Parameters.habitat_description: Peromyscus keeni is a forest species of the Coastal and Cascades ranges in Washington State.  It has been considered a species limited to closed-canopy stands, but Gitzen and West (2002) found it in small canopy gaps and Taylor (1999) captured them in grass-forb, shrub-sapling, open sapling-pole, closed sapling-pole, and old-growth western hemlock forest stands in the Olympic Peninsula.

GAP Modeling Database Parameters.habitat_description:
Southeast/Upper Midwest:
"The natural habitat of wapiti is forested mountain terrain and plains. Elk in Michigan thrive in a mixed open and woodland environment. In summer they occupy areas of aspen/hardwood forest broken up by numerous openings. In winter they inhabit swampy areas with conifers, cutover areas, aspen/hardwoods, and upland conifer/hardwoods with openings" (Whitaker 1998). Elk reintroduced to Kentucky occupy forest landscapes with large openings such as those created by mine reclaimation. They primarily use forested ridgetops, upper sideslopes, grassy openings, and shrubby edges of floodplains (Trani et al. 2007).

Northeast:
Elk in Pennsylvania occupy forested landscapes of the Allegheny Plateau at elevations between 900 and 2300 feet (274 - 701 m). This area is a south-north transition zone between mixed oak-hickory and northern hardwood deciduous forests (Cogan and Diefenbach 1998, O'Gara and Dundas 2002).

Southwest/Northwest:
Common in most mountainous regions of Utah. Found in mountain meadows and forests during the summer and in foothills and valley grasslands during winter. They avoid deep snow.  Associated with semiopen forests or forest edges adjacent to parks, meadows, alpine tundra. In Colorado, the species ranges throughout the western two-thirds of state generally at elevations above 1800 m. Habitat: semiopen forest, mountain meadows, foothills, plains, valleys. Uses open areas such as alpine pastures, marshy meadows, river flats, aspen parkland, coniferous forest, brushy clear cuts, forest edges, and semi-desert areas. Elk in non-roaded habitats increased use of open timber types; in roaded habitat, they increased use of closed canopy timbered types. Begin moving down to exposed southern slopes at lower elevations when deepening snow piles up to about 20 inches (500 mm). At the present time, elk do well in Arizona in the mountainous areas that have extensive stands of forest. Small, isolated mountain ranges, with limited coniferous forest, do not provide good areas for elk.
In California, Tule Elk (Cervus elaphus nannodes) introduced to the Owens Valley use brush, scrub and herbaceous habitats year-round (McCullough 1969, [Alhorn et al. in CAWHR] based on Zeiner et al. 1990). In other parts of the state, C. e. roosevelti and C. e. nelsoni utilize open, brushy stands of deciduous and coniferous habitats (both forest and woodlands) as well as riparian areas, meadows, and herbaceous early successional forest environments ([Alhorn et al. in CAWHR] based on Zeiner et al. 1990).
In Oregon, elk are most abundant in the Blue and Wallowa mountains and northern coast range while being less abundant in the arid southeastern regions. Habitat is a mosaic of early succesional stages with abundant herbaceous forage, and later successional forested habitats that provide cover. In the western part of the state, early successional foraging habitats are most often provided by clearcut and burned forest stands (Verts and Carraway 1998). In the Blue Mountains, Leckenby (1984) found that >80% of foraging habitat for elk consisted of a forest/open ecotone 600 yards (550 m) wide. Ecotones of forest/woodland and early successional and shrub habitats are very important landscape features of high quality elk habitat (Skovlin et al. 2002). In general, habitat management guidelines for elk recommend maintaining landscapes that provide 40% cover and 60% forage consisting of tall shrub, woodland, and forested habitat; and open spaces of low shrub and herbaceous vegetation respectively (Skovlin et al. 2002).

mNADEx-y6.memHandModelNotes: Hand Modeling: Two separate models should be run for this species and then merged due to segregation of habitat usage by subsppecies P.m. nubiterrea and P.m. bairdii. ***For P.m. nubiterrae: run model within Allegheny-Cumberland Mountain and Appalachian Regions regions of range only, use landform and elevation restrictors on forested/woodland ecosystems, DO NOT include prairie, any anthropogenic, glade or uncosolidated shore classes in this model. Could not find documenting source for elevation parameters listed by NC-GAP & GA-GAP, Ky-GAP 820m & slope affinity (Barbour & Davis 1974). ****For P.m. bairdii  (Prairie deer mouse) run model in Interior Plateau and Coastal Plain portions of range only. DO NOT include any Forested or Woodland ecosystems in model or landform and elevation parameters, use only open, disturbed, prairie ecosystems.  ****Merge separate models together for final predicted distribution of deer mouse.   Amy Silvano 24jun05

GAP Modeling Database Parameters.habitat_description:
The North American Deermouse (Peromyscus maniculatus) has the most extensive range of any North American rodent, and is found in almost every kind of habitat (Smithsonian 2016).  The taxonomy of this species is uncertain, however, and may actually include populations that warrant species status.  Numerous subspecies are currently recognized and have more restrictive habitat needs than the species as a whole.  Some are described below.

Deer Mice use a wide variety of upland and riparian habitats from open areas and brushlands to coniferous and deciduous forests. The range of this species extends southward from general forested habitats in the northeastern United States and Canada to the southeastern limit of its breeding range in the southern Appalachians, where, in North Carolina, it occurs on mountain slopes and peaks and in some foothill locations (Lee et al. 1982, Brown 1997).

Within the southern Appalachian region, the species is largely associated with cool, moist mixed conifer and deciduous forests or conifer forests (Brown 1997, Whitaker and Hamilton 1998), and also with deciduous forests which contain evergreen shrub thickets (Webster et al. 1985). Rocky, mossy conditions or areas with numerous downed and decaying logs and stumps are favorable nesting and denning sites (Webster et al. 1985).

P. m. bairdii prefers open weedfield, abandoned cropland, grasslands, sandy areas and any place cleared of trees (Barbour & Davis 1974, Whitaker & Hamilton 1998).  P.m. nubiterrae uses woodland, mixed woods, conifers, hardwoods. It is found in all habitats in higher mountian elevation and restricted to dense forests of birch, beech, and maple where forest floor stays cool and moist - farther down mountians (Barbout & Davis 1974).  

In the Southwest, P. maniculatus occurs in tundra, Rocky Mountain alpine and subalpine grassland, plains grassland, open, sparsely vegetated deserts, warm temperate swamp and riparian forests, and Sonoran desertscrub (Thompson et al. 1996, Davis and Schmidly 1997). PNV (BLM) - Shortgrass prairies, sactan grassland, and sycamore and rabbitbrush riparian (Thompson et al. 1996). The species is most common in ponderosa, mixed coniferous, and spruce - fir forests; next most common in northern sage-grassland; and much less common in woodland, grassland, and desert communities (Thompson et al. 1996). In more southern areas, the species may inhabit sandy areas with P. leucopus (Thompson et al. 1996). In southern New Mexico, the indigenous species of Peromyscus in the woodland zone act as a barrier between the montane and lowland populations of P. maniculatus (Thompson et al. 1996).  In Colorado, it is found in all habitats with cover, except well-developed wetlands (Fitzgerald et al. 1994). It avoids poorly drained soils (Thompson et al. 1996). It occurs in most habitats at all elevations in Colorado (Fitzgerald et al. 1994). P. maniculatus exploits disturbed habitats: overgrazed, cleared, mined, construction sites, burned, and avalanche or landslide areas (Fitzgerald et al. 1994). It should be found in all the mountains of New Mexico (New Mexico Department of Game and Fish 2000).  P. maniculatus occurs among aspen, cottonwood - willow, pinyon - juniper, bristlecone pine, limber pine, Chihuahuan pine, Apache pine, Gambel's oak, Toumey's oak, broom snakeweed, fourwing saltbush, saltcedar, Russian olive, crested wheatgrass, western wheatgrass, sixweeks fescue, Indian ricegrass, sand sage, winter-fat, creosote, tarbush, ocotillo, redberry juniper, silverleaf and netleaf oaks, shinnery oak scrub, sedges, grama and buffalograss, galleta, big bluestem, sand bluestem, alkali sacaton, tobosa, bluejoint, ricegrass, alder, Apache plume, mesquite, rushes, cattails, three-awn-finger grass, bluejoint - switchgrass, sand plum thickets, saltcedar - groundsel tree, yucca, beargrass, allthorn, ephedra, and ribes (Thompson et al. 1996).  It eats almost anything - seeds, carrion, bone, fungi, leaves, and bark (Fitzgerald et al. 1994).  

The home range is 0.2ha (New Mexico Department of Game and Fish 2000). The elevation is 305-3963m (Thompson et al. 1996).  P. maniculatus occurs throughout the southwest (Hoffmeister 1986, Fitzgerald et al. 1994, Hall 1995, Utah GAP 1997, Frey 2004). Can be found in the following mountain ranges: Ruby Mountains; Sulpher Spring Range; Snake Mountains; Animas Mountains; San Andres Mountains; Pinaleno Mountains; Manzano Mountains; Hualapai Mountains; Chuska Mountains; Tunitcha Mountains; White Mountains; Lukachukai Mountains; Juniper Mountains; Gila Mountains; Blue Range; Santa Catalina Mountains, Chirichua Mountains; Huachuca Mountains; Mohave Mountains; Santa Rita Mountains; Pinr Forest Range; Gramite Range (Washoe); Fox Range; Carson Range; Cambridge Hills; Kamma Mountains; Excelsior Mountains; Silver Peak Range; Cartez Mountains; Palmetto Mountains; Shosshone Mountains; Tioyabe Range; Toquima Range; Monitor Range; Hot Creek Range; San Antonio Mountains; Quinn Canyon Range; Kawich Range; Belted Range; Cactus Range; Jarbridge Mountains.

GAP Modeling Database Parameters.habitat_description:
Southwest:
T. minimus occurs in pinyon-juniper, greasewood, rabbitbrush, scrub and live oaks, grama and buffalograss, galleta and ricegrass, ponderosa forest, cottonwood, alder, and willow (Findley et al. 1975, Sullivan and Peterson 1988, Thompson et al. 1996, New Mexico Department of Game and Fish 2002). It is found in alpine and subalpine grassland, alpine talus slides, sage plains, forested woodland bordered by sandstone ledges, the edges of spruce-fir forest, tundra, and juniper savannah (Findley et al. 1975, Thompson et al. 1996, New Mexico Department of Game and Fish 2002). PNV - mixed "short-grass", Great Basin Desertscrub, low, semi-arid sagebrush and greasewood desert, through brushy ravines (Thompson et al. 1996). In Colorado, the species is associated with clearings or subclimax grassland (Thompson et al. 1996). It is strongly associated with shrubs at forest edges, disturbed areas, and forest ecotones (Thompson et al. 1996). The Penasco subspecies is found in more open situations, including fencerows bordering agriculture fields and open stands of trees (Thompson et al. 1996). Shrublands and forest clearings are necessary for adult feeding (Thompson et al. 1996). T. minimus eats Vaccinium berries and strawberries, fungi, Russian thistle, currants, prickly pear, thistle, and fleabane (Fitzgerald et al. 1994, Hall 1995). It eats the seeds of gilia, bitterroot, sedges, violet, evening primrose, common wild geranium, and grass (Fitzgerald et al. 1994). It eats the flowers of alpine parsley, dandelion, and paintbrush (Fitzgerald et al. 1994). The home range varies from 0.2 ha to 1.6 ha (Fitzgerald et al. 1994, NatureServe 2001). Maximum distances between captures was 143 to 413 m (Fitzgerald et al. 1994). T. minimus is most frequently found on slopes less than 22 degrees, but may be found on slopes even greater than 67 degrees (Sullivan 1985, New Mexico Department of Game and Fish 2002). The elevation is from 1,220-3,900m (Hall 1995, New Mexico Department of Game and Fish 2002). Elevation: up to 2800 m. in Nevada, up to 3000 m. in New Mexico, up to 3900 in Colorado (Jezkova 2005). The species retreats to burrows in cold weather (Thompson et al. 1996). T. minimus occurs on the Kaibab Plateau, Chuska-Lukachukai Mountains, and White Mountains in Arizona (Cockrum 1960, Hoffmeister 1986). It is found in the western two-thirds of Colorado (Fitzgerald et al. 1994). The species is present in the northern two-thirds of Nevada except for the low western valleys, probably due to the lack of sagebrush in them (Hall 1995). The chipmunk is found in the Sacramento, Chuska, San Juan, Jemez, Sangre de Cristo, and Sandia mountains in New Mexico (Findley et al. 1975, Frey 2004). The species occurs throughout Utah (Durrant 1952, Utah GAP 1997). It is found in the Sierra Blanca, Sacramento Mountains, Sandia Mountains, Santa Fe Mountains, Sangre de Cristo Mountains, Jemez Mountains, Tunitcha Mountains, White Mountains, San Juan Mountains, Lukachukai Mountains, Blue Range,  Wasatch Range, Gallinas Mountains, Chuska Mountains, Granite Range in Washoe County, Humboldt Range, East Humboldt Range, Shoshone Mountains, Toquima Range, Monitor Range, Quinn Canyon Mountains, Kawich Mountains, Schell Creek Range, Silver Peak Range, and the Tunitcha Mountains. In California, this species is fairly common in sagebrush, bitterbrush, and various Great Basin shrub habitats. It may also inhabit the brushy understory of open Jeffrey pine and pinyon-juniper areas as well as alpine dwarf-shrub habitats in higher elevation mountain environments ([Harris et al. 2007] based on Zeiner et al. 1990).

Northwest:
In Washington, this species inhabits shrubsteppe or open forest habitats including sagebrush (Artemisia spp.), antelope bitterbrush, and greasewood and are rarely found in grasslands or closed forest. Most habitat use is adjacent to shrubsteppe and/or open forest and may also utilize low density urban and open space when adjacent to shrubsteppe. Alpine meadows are not within T. minimus' range in the state of Washington (WHCWG 2010, Dalquest 1948, Johnson and Cassidy 1997, Larrison 1947, Feldhamer 1979). In Oregon, T. minimus occurs in shrubsteppe and occasionally open forest edges of ponderosa pine and shrubsteppe. They will also occur in aspen groves with rocky outcrops, sagebrush, greaswood and within heavy soils (such as clays) and avoid grasslands and marshes (Verts and Carraway 1998, Hansen 1956, Feldhamer 1979).

Upper Midwest:
"In northern Minnesota, T. minimus was associated with 'recently logged or burned areas, in disturbed habitats around campsites and resorts, and along the rocky shore of Lake Superior’ (Timm 1975). The species also was taken in early seral stands of black spruce (Picea mariana), black ash (Fraxinus nigra), and balsam fir (Abies balsamea) but was replaced by T. striatus in stands of mature pine. In the Upper Peninsula of Michigan, T. minimus occurs 'in dense upland forest, hardwoods and conifers alike, but it also frequents swamps of white cedar, black spruce, alder, and leatherleaf, as well as rocky and sandy shores, recently burned or cutover areas, rocky  mountain-tops, cleared lands, and openings in the forest grown up to brambles and brush' (Manville 1949). However, in the same region, habitats with good horizontal visibility, medium to dense brush piles, and open canopies were occupied significantly more than habitats with other characteristics (Reilly 1971)." (quoted directly from Verts and Carrway 2001).
